Docs.summary: This is a primary interface in a COM coclass that is required by managed code for interoperability with the corresponding COM object. Use this primary interface only when the method you want to use shares the same name as an event of the COM object; in this case, cast to this interface to call the method, and cast to the latest events interface to connect to the event. Otherwise, use the .NET interface that is derived from the COM coclass to access methods, properties, and events of the COM object. For information about the COM object, see .

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Actions As Actions

Docs.summary: Returns an collection that represents all the available actions for the item. Read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool AllDayEvent { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Returns True if the appointment is an all-day event (as opposed to a specified time). Read/write.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Application As Application

Docs.summary: Returns an object that represents the parent Outlook application for the object. Read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Attachments As Attachments

Docs.summary: Returns an object that represents all the attachments for the specified item. Read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property AutoResolvedWinner As Boolean
public: property bool AutoResolvedWinner { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a Boolean (bool in C#) that determines if the item is a winner of an automatic conflict resolution. Read-only.

remarks.para: A value of False does not necessarily indicate that the item is a loser of an automatic conflict resolution. The item could be in conflict with another item.

If an item has of its property greater than zero and if its AutoResolvedWinner property is True, it is a winner of an automatic conflict resolution. On the other hand, if the item is in conflict and has its AutoResolvedWinner property as False, it is a loser in an automatic conflict resolution.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ BillingInformation { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a String (string in C#) representing the billing information associated with the Outlook item. Read/write.

remarks.para: This is a free-form text field.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Body { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a String (string in C#) representing the clear-text body of the Outlook item. Read/write.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlBusyStatus BusyStatus { Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlBusyStatus get(); void set(Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlBusyStatus value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets an constant indicating the busy status of the user for the appointment. Read/write.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Categories { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a String (string in C#) representing the categories assigned to the Outlook item. Read/write.

remarks.para: Categories is a delimited string of category names that have been assigned to an Outlook item. This property uses the character specified in the value name, sList, under HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\International in the Windows registry, as the delimiter for multiple category values. To convert the string of category names to an array of category names, use the Microsoft Visual Basic function Split.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property ConversationID As String
public: property System::String ^ ConversationID { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a String (string in C#) that uniquely identifies a object that the object belongs to. Read-only.

remarks.para: This property associates items with a conversation. These items and the conversation all have the same value in their ConversationID property.
This property corresponds with the MAPI property PidTagConversationId.

If the AppointmentItem object is created in a version of Microsoft Outlook earlier than Microsoft Outlook 2010, or if Outlook is running in online mode against a version of Microsoft Exchange Server earlier than Microsoft Exchange Server 2010, this property returns the same value as the property.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance object Copy() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Creates another instance of an object.
Docs.returns: Returns an that is a copy of the parent appointment item.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.AppointmentItem CopyTo([in]class Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.MAPIFolder DestinationFolder, [in]valuetype Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.OlAppointmentCopyOptions CopyOptions) runtime managed
Public Function CopyTo (DestinationFolder As MAPIFolder, CopyOptions As OlAppointmentCopyOptions) As AppointmentItem

Docs.param: Specifies the folder to which the AppointmentItem object is copied.
Specifies the user experience of the copy operation.
Docs.summary: Copies the to the folder that is specified by the parameter and returns an object that represents the item created in the destination folder by the copy operation.
Docs.returns: Returns an AppointmentItem object that represents the object created in the destination folder as a result of the copy operation.

remarks.para: If no argument is specified for the parameter, CopyTo assumes that the value is olCreateAppointment.

CopyTo returns an error if the destination folder is not an appropriate folder type for an AppointmentItem object, or if the user does not have the necessary permissions to create items in the specified destination folder.
Setting the REG_MULTI_SZ value, DisableCrossAccountCopy, in HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Office\14.0\Outlook in the Windows registry has the side effect of disabling this method.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property CreationTime As DateTime
public: property DateTime CreationTime { DateTime get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a DateTime indicating the creation time for the Outlook item. Read-only.

remarks.para: This property corresponds to the MAPI property PidTagCreationTime.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Delete() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Removes the item from the folder that contains the item.

remarks.para: The Delete method deletes a single item in a collection. To delete all items in the collection of a folder, you must delete each item starting with the last item in the folder. For example, in the items collection of a folder, AllItems, if there are n number of items in the folder, start deleting the item at AllItems.Item(n), decrementing the index each time until you delete AllItems.Item(1).
The Delete method moves the item from the containing folder to the Deleted Items folder. If the containing folder is the Deleted Items folder, the Delete method removes the item permanently.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Display([in]object Modal) runtime managed
Public Sub Display (Optional Modal As Object)

Docs.param: True to make the window modal. The default value is False.
Docs.summary: Displays a new object for the item.

remarks.para: The Display method is supported for explorer and inspector windows for the sake of backward compatibility. To activate an explorer or inspector window, use the method.

If you attempt to open an "unsafe" file system object (or "freedoc" file) by using the Microsoft Outlook object model, you receive the E_FAIL return code in the C or C++ programming languages. In Outlook 2000 and earlier, you could open an "unsafe" file system object by using the Display method.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property DateTime EndInEndTimeZone { DateTime get(); void set(DateTime value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a DateTime value that represents the end date and time of the appointment expressed in the . Read/write.

remarks.para: This is the value displayed as End time in the appointment inspector user interface.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::TimeZone ^ EndTimeZone { Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::TimeZone ^ get(); void set(Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::TimeZone ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a value that corresponds to the end time of the appointment. Read/write.

remarks.para: The time zone information is used to map the appointment to the correct UTC time when the appointment is saved, and into the correct local time when the item is displayed in the calendar.
Changing EndTimeZone affects the value of which is always represented in the local time zone, .
Depending on the circumstances, changing the EndTimeZone may or may not cause Outlook to recalculate and update the .

As an example, in the appointment inspector, if you are the organizer of an appointment with a start time at 1 P.M. EST and end time at 3 P.M. EST, changing the appointment to have an EndTimeZone of PST will result in an appointment lasting from 1 P.M. EST to 3 P.M. PST, with the EndInEndTimeZone remaining as 3 P.M.. However, if you are not the organizer, then changing the EndTimeZone from EST to PST will cause Outlook to recalculate and update the EndInEndTimeZone, and the appointment will last from 1 P.M. EST to 12 P.M. PST.

Another example is changing the EndTimeZone resulting in an appointment end time that occurs before a previously set appointment start time, in which case Outlook will recalculate and update the EndInEndTimeZone. For example, an appointment with a start time at 1 P.M. PST and end time at 3 P.M. PST has its EndTimeZone changed to EST. If Outlook did not recalculate the EndInEndTimeZone, the appointment would have an end time at 3 P.M. EST, which is equivalent to 12 P.M. PST, and which would occur before the start time of 1 P.M. PST. In practice, however, changing the EndTimeZone would result in Outlook recalculating and updating the EndInEndTimeZone to 6 P.M. (in the EndTimeZone EST).

MemberSignature.Value: public: property DateTime EndUTC { DateTime get(); void set(DateTime value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a DateTime value that represents the end date and time of the appointment expressed in the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) standard. Read/write.

remarks.para: Changing the value for the property or the property will cause Outlook to recalculate the EndUTC.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property EntryID As String
public: property System::String ^ EntryID { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a String (string in C#) representing the unique Entry ID of the object. Read-only.

remarks.para: This property corresponds to the MAPI property PidTagEntryId.

A MAPI store provider assigns a unique ID string when an item is created in its store. Therefore, the EntryID property is not set for an Outlook item until it is saved or sent. The Entry ID changes when an item is moved into another store, for example, from your Inbox to a Microsoft Exchange Server public folder, or from one Personal Folders (.pst) file to another .pst file. Solutions should not depend on the EntryID property to be unique unless items will not be moved. The EntryID property returns a MAPI long-term Entry ID. For more information about long- and short-term EntryIDs, search http://msdn.microsoft.com for PidTagEntryId.

Furthermore, when you call the AppointmentItem.Respond method with the olMeetingAccepted or olMeetingTentative parameter, Outlook will create a new appointment item that duplicates the original appointment item. The new item will have a different Entry ID. Outlook will then remove the original item. You should no longer use the Entry ID of the original item, but instead use AppointmentItem.EntryID to obtain the Entry ID for the new item for any subsequent needs. This is to ensure that this appointment item will be properly synchronized on your calendar if more than one client computer accesses your calendar but may be offline using the cache mode occasionally.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool ForceUpdateToAllAttendees { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a Boolean (bool in C#) value that indicates whether updates to the object should be sent to all attendees. Read/write.

remarks.para: Normally, updates are sent to attendees only if the time or location of an appointment item is changed. Setting this property to True forces an update to be sent to all attendees, even if no changes to the time or location has occurred.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property FormDescription As FormDescription

Docs.summary: Returns the object that represents the form description for the specified Outlook item. Read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.MailItem ForwardAsVcal() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Forwards the as a vCal; virtual calendar item.
Docs.returns: A object that represents the new mail item to which the calendar information is attached.

remarks.para: The ForwardAsVcal method returns a with the vCal file attached.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.Conversation GetConversation() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Obtains a object that represents the conversation to which this item belongs.
Docs.returns: Returns a Conversation object that represents the conversation to which this item belongs.

remarks.para: GetConversation returns Nothing (a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) in C#) if no conversation exists for the item. No conversation exists for an item in the following scenarios:

item.para: The item has not been saved. An item can be saved programmatically, by user action, or by auto-save.
For an item that can be sent (for example, a mail item, appointment item, or contact item), the item has not been sent.
Conversations have been disabled through the Windows registry.

The store does not support the conversation view (for example, Outlook is running in classic online mode against a version of Microsoft Exchange earlier than Microsoft Exchange Server 2010). Use the property of the object to determine whether the store supports the conversation view.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property GetInspector As Inspector

Docs.summary: Returns an object that represents an inspector initialized to contain the specified item. Read-only.

remarks.para: This property is useful for returning a new Inspector object in which to display the item, as opposed to using the method and setting the property. If an Inspector object already exists for the item, the GetInspector property will return that Inspector object instead of creating a new one.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.AddressEntry GetOrganizer() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Obtains the object that contains information from the Address Book about the organizer of the .
Docs.returns: Returns an AddressEntry object that represents the organizer of the AppointmentItem.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.RecurrencePattern GetRecurrencePattern() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Returns a object that represents the recurrence attributes of an appointment.
Docs.returns: A RecurrencePattern object that represents the recurrence attributes of an appointment.

remarks.para: If there is no existing recurrence pattern, a new empty RecurrencePattern object is returned.

When you work with recurring appointment items, you should release any prior references, obtain new references to the recurring appointment item before you access or modify the item, and release these references as soon as you are finished and have saved the changes. This practice applies to the recurring object, and any or object. To release a reference in Visual Basic, set that existing object to Nothing. In C#, explicitly release the memory for that object.

Note that even after you release your reference and attempt to obtain a new reference, if there is still an active reference, held by another add-in or Outlook, to one of the above objects, your new reference will still point to an out-of-date copy of the object. Therefore, it is important that you release your references as soon as you are finished with the recurring appointment.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property GlobalAppointmentID As String
public: property System::String ^ GlobalAppointmentID { System::String ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a String (string in C#) value that represents a unique global identifier for the object. Read-only.

remarks.para: There are situations where the entry ID of AppointmentItem objects may change, such as when an item is moved to a different folder or to a different store. Entry IDs can also change when a user performs certain functions in Outlook, such as exporting and then reimporting data.

Therefore, each Outlook appointment item is assigned a Global Object ID, a unique global identifier which does not change during those situations. The Global Object ID is a MAPI property that Outlook uses to correlate meeting updates and responses with a particular meeting on the calendar. The Global Object ID is the same across all copies of the item.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlImportance Importance { Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlImportance get(); void set(Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlImportance value); };

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsConflict As Boolean
public: property bool IsConflict { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a Boolean (bool in C#) that determines if the item on the local computer is different from the copy on the server. Read-only.

remarks.para: Whether or not an item is in conflict is determined by the state of the application. For example, when a user is offline and tries to access an online folder, the action will fail. In this scenario, the IsConflict property will return True.
This property does not indicate whether the appointment item has a time conflict with another appointment in the calendar.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ MessageClass { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a String (string in C#) representing the message class for the Outlook item. Read/write.

MemberSignature.Value: public Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.MeetingItem Respond (Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.OlMeetingResponse Response, object fNoUI, object fAdditionalTextDialog);

.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.MeetingItem Respond([in]valuetype Microsoft.Office.Interop.Outlook.OlMeetingResponse Response, [in]object fNoUI, [in]object fAdditionalTextDialog) runtime managed
Public Function Respond (Response As OlMeetingResponse, Optional fNoUI As Object, Optional fAdditionalTextDialog As Object) As MeetingItem

Docs.param: True to not display a dialog box; the response is sent automatically. False to display the dialog box for responding.

False to not prompt the user for input; the response is displayed in the inspector for editing. True to prompt the user to either send or send with comments. This argument is valid only if fNoUI is False.
Docs.summary: Responds to a meeting request.
Docs.returns: A object that represents the response to the meeting request.

remarks.para: When you call the Respond method with the olMeetingAccepted or olMeetingTentative parameter, Outlook will create a new appointment item that duplicates the original appointment item. The new item will have a different Entry ID. Outlook will then remove the original item. You should no longer use the Entry ID of the original item, but instead call the property to obtain the Entry ID for the new item for any subsequent needs. This is to ensure that this appointment item will be properly synchronized on your calendar if more than one client computer accesses your calendar but may be offline using the cache mode occasionally.
The following table describes the behavior of the Respond method depending on the parent object, and the and parameters.

item.description: Response item is returned with no user interface. To send the response, you must call the Send method.
Same result as with True, True.
Prompts user to Send or Edit before sending the response.
New response item appears in the user interface, but no prompt is displayed.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool ResponseRequested { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Returns a Boolean (bool in C#) that indicates True if the sender would like a response to the meeting request for the appointment. Read/write.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property ResponseStatus As OlResponseStatus

Docs.summary: Returns an constant indicating the overall status of the meeting for the current user for the appointment. Read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Object ^ RTFBody { System::Object ^ get(); void set(System::Object ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a byte array that represents the body of the Microsoft Outlook item in Rich Text Format. Read/write.

remarks.para: You can use the System.Text.Encoding.AsciiEncoding.GetString() method in C# or Visual Basic to convert an array of bytes to a string.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Save() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Saves the Microsoft Outlook item to the current folder or, if this is a new item, to the Outlook default folder for the item type.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SaveAs (string Path, object Type);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void SaveAs([in]string Path, [in]object Type) runtime managed
Public Sub SaveAs (Path As String, Optional Type As Object)

Docs.param: The path in which to save the item.
The file type to save. Can be one of the following OlSaveAsType constants: olHTML, olMSG, olRTF, olTemplate, olDoc,olTXT, olVCal, olVCard, olICal, or olMSGUnicode.
Docs.summary: Saves the Microsoft Outlook item to the specified path and in the format of the specified file type. If the file type is not specified, the MSG format (.msg) is used.

remarks.para: Also note that even though olDoc is a valid OlSaveAsType constant, messages in HTML format cannot be saved in Document format, and the olDoc constant works only if Microsoft Word is set up as the default email editor.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Saved As Boolean
public: property bool Saved { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a Boolean (bool in C#) value that is True if the Outlook item has not been modified since the last save. Read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Send() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Sends the appointment.

remarks.para: The Send method sends an item using the default account specified for the session. In a session where multiple Microsoft Exchange accounts are defined in the profile, the first Exchange account added to the profile is the primary Exchange account, and is also the default account for the session. To specify a different account to send an item, set the property to the desired object and then call the Send method.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::Account ^ SendUsingAccount { Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::Account ^ get(); void set(Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::Account ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets an object that represents the account under which the is to be sent. Read/write.

remarks.para: The SendUsingAccount property can be used to specify the account that should be used to send the AppointmentItem when the method is called. This property returns Nothing (a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) in C#) if the account specified for the AppointmentItem no longer exists.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlSensitivity Sensitivity { Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlSensitivity get(); void set(Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::OlSensitivity value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a constant in the enumeration indicating the sensitivity for the Outlook item. Read/write.

remarks.para: This property corresponds to the MAPI property PidTagSensitivity.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Session As NameSpace

Docs.summary: Returns the object for the current session. Read-only.

remarks.para: The Session property and the method can be used interchangeably to obtain the NameSpace object for the current session. Both members serve the same purpose. For example, the following pairs of statements perform the same function:

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void ShowCategoriesDialog() runtime managed

Docs.summary: Displays the Show Categories dialog box, which allows you to select categories that correspond to the subject of the item.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property Size As Integer
public: property int Size { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns an Integer (int in C#) value indicating the size (in bytes) of the Outlook item. Read-only.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property DateTime Start { DateTime get(); void set(DateTime value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a DateTime indicating the starting date and time for the Outlook item. Read/write.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property DateTime StartInStartTimeZone { DateTime get(); void set(DateTime value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a DateTime value that represents the start date and time of the appointment expressed in the . Read/write.

remarks.para: This is the value displayed as Start time in the appointment inspector user interface.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::TimeZone ^ StartTimeZone { Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::TimeZone ^ get(); void set(Microsoft::Office::Interop::Outlook::TimeZone ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a value that corresponds to the time zone for the start time of the appointment. Read/write.

remarks.para: The time zone information is used to map the appointment to the correct UTC time when the appointment is saved, and into the correct local time when the item is displayed in the calendar.
Changing StartTimeZone affects the value of which is always represented in the local time zone, .
Depending on the circumstances, changing the StartTimeZone may or may not cause Outlook to recalculate and update the .

As an example, in the appointment inspector, if you are the organizer of an appointment with a start time at 1 P.M. PST and end time at 3 P.M. PST, changing the appointment to have an StartTimeZone of EST will result in an appointment lasting from 1 P.M. EST to 3 P.M. PST, with the StartInStartTimeZone remaining as 1 P.M. However, if you are not the organizer, then changing the StartTimeZone from PST to EST will cause Outlook to recalculate and update the StartInStartTimeZone, and the appointment will last from 4 P.M. EST to 3 P.M. PST.

Another example is changing the StartTimeZone resulting in an appointment end time that occurs before a previously set appointment start time, in which case Outlook will recalculate and update the StartInStartTimeZone. For example, an appointment with a start time at 1 P.M. EST and end time at 3 P.M. EST has its StartTimeZone changed to PST. If Outlook did not recalculate the StartInStartTimeZone, the appointment would have a start time at 1 P.M. PST, which is equivalent to 4 P.M. EST, and which would occur before the end time of 3 P.M. EST. In practice, however, changing the StartTimeZone would result in Outlook recalculating and updating the StartInStartTimeZone to 10 A.M. (in the StartTimeZone PST).

MemberSignature.Value: public: property DateTime StartUTC { DateTime get(); void set(DateTime value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a DateTime value that represents the start date and time of the appointment expressed in the Coordinated Univeral Time (UTC) standard. Read/write.

remarks.para: Changing the value for the property or the property will cause Outlook to recalculate the value of StartUTC.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Subject { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a String (string in C#) indicating the subject for the Outlook item. Read/write.

remarks.para: This property corresponds to the MAPI property PidTagSubject. The Subject property is the default property for Outlook items.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool UnRead { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Returns or sets a Boolean (bool in C#) value that is True if the Outlook item has not been opened (read). Read/write.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property UserProperties As UserProperties

Docs.summary: Returns the collection that represents all the user properties for the Outlook item. Read-only.
